title: Chat: Guided mode/prompt creation for slash command (prompt)

labels.name: chat-prompts
labels.description: Prompt and Instruction files related issues

body:
How might an agentic flow help to create prompts and modes.

Example Claude Code `/agents - Create new agent` flow:
1.  _Create new agent_
   No agents found. Create specialized subagents that Claude can delegate to.                                                                      
   Each subagent has its own context window, custom system prompt, and specific tools.                                                             
   Try creating: Code Reviewer, Code Simplifier, Security Reviewer, Tech Lead, or UX Reviewer.
2. _Choose location_ (Project, Personal)
3. _Creation method_ (Generate with Claude (recommended), Manual configuration)
2. _Describe what this agent should do and when it should be used (be comprehensive for best results)_
3. LLM-generates _description_ (with when, how and examples) and _system prompt_.
4. Pick tools from 4 categories (or advanced from all tools)
5. _Select model (Model determines the agent's reasoning capabilities and speed.)_
6. _Step 6: Choose background color_
7. Preview and Save

title: Add mouse drag scrolling to scrollable element and hover widget
body:
Adds functionality based on issue #239704.

This PR adds `AbstractScrollableElement` functionality to include mouse drag scrolling in the hover widget. By default, `handleDragScroll` is disabled and will not be triggered in the main editor view. This is selectively enabled within the `ui/hover/hoverWidget` component.

## Demonstration

![Recording 2025-08-12 215730](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/110aad6b-c58d-4bd5-8d8c-71e248239e09)

## How to test
In Visual Studio Code, hover over some text that has a definition, or anything that triggers the `HoverWidget`. Press and hold the left mouse button anywhere in the text inside the hover info widget, and move the mouse up to the top, or the bottom of it. You can also scroll from left to right.

title: Clean up built-in tool groups for affordance and to ease usage in in modes/prompts
body:
Configuring tools on the fly for chat request, or for modes and prompts is confusing due to the wild grouping. It is extremely hard to make effective planning or test-driven modes as the needed tools are fragmented.

**Current list**
- changes
- codebase
- editFiles
  - insertEdit
  - replaceString
  - applyPatch
  - createFile
  - createDirectory
  - editNotebook
  - newJupyterNotebook
- extensions
- fetch
- findTestFiles
- githubRepo
- new
- openSimpleBrowser
- problems
- readNotebookCellOutput
- runCommands
- runNotebooks
- runTasks
- runTests
- search
  - fileSearch
  - textSearch
  - listDirectory
  - readNotebookCellOutput
  - readFile
- searchResults
- terminalLastCommand
- terminalSelection
- testFailure
- todos
- usages
- vscodeApi

**Observations:**

- Important groups like `search` are further down
- Fragmented across 2+ entries, lacking groups:
   - tests (cc @connor4312)
   - terminal (cc @Tyriar)
   - Notebook tools (cc @DonJayamanne)
- `codebase` is just semantic search, `search` has the actual file search and read
- A few should be user-controlled `#context` entries (`searchResults`, `testFailure`, `terminalLastCommand`, …) and not agentic tools

cc @ntrogh who did the last copy cleanup, for thoughts.
cc @aeschli how might we make tool name migration easier when defined in modes/prompts, like aliasing the old names?
cc @jo-oikawa for UX input.

**Cleanup brainstorming:**

- ~built-in~
- _read-only_ (smart group where users can opt more tools in via settings)
   - searches, findtestfiles, usages, changes, …
   - web
   - _(… more read-only tools if configured)_
- _edit_
- terminal
- run _(tasks & tests)_
- notebooks
- ???

---

**Examples** of easy to understand groups from other AI coding tools:

Tool 1:
- Search
  - Codebase
  - Web
  - Grep
  - List directory
  - Search files
  - Read file
  - Fetch rules
- Edit
  - Edit & Reapply
  - Delete file
- Run
  - Terminal
- MCP Servers

Tool 2:
- Read-only tools
- Edit tools
- Execution tools
- MCP tools

title: Fix TodoList Tool keyboard accessibility and screen reader support
body:
The TodoList Tool in VS Code's chat feature was not accessible via keyboard navigation and lacked proper screen reader support. Users could not navigate individual todo items with keyboard or get meaningful announcements from assistive technology.

## Changes Made

### Semantic Structure & ARIA Support
- Replaced generic div containers with semantic `<ul role="list">` and `<li role="listitem">` structure
- Added comprehensive ARIA attributes including `aria-label`, `aria-describedby`, and `aria-controls`
- Enhanced expand button with proper `aria-expanded` state management

### Keyboard Navigation
- **Arrow Keys**: Up/Down navigation between todo items
- **Home/End Keys**: Jump to first/last items
- **Tab Navigation**: Logical tab order through expand button and todo items
- **Enter/Space**: Toggle expand/collapse functionality

### Screen Reader Enhancements
- Each todo item now announces title, status, and description: *"Create accessible UI components, not started"*
- Added hidden status text elements for detailed screen reader information
- Marked decorative status icons with `aria-hidden="true"`
- Implemented `getStatusText()` method with localized status descriptions

### Visual Focus Indicators
- Added clear focus borders using VS Code's standard design tokens
- Implemented hover states consistent with the VS Code design system
- Enhanced CSS with proper focus management and visual feedback

### Testing
- Created comprehensive test suite validating semantic structure, ARIA attributes, and keyboard navigation
- Manual testing confirmed proper keyboard navigation and screen reader announcements
- Verified compatibility with existing functionality

![TodoList Widget Accessibility Demo](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/45f2df22-155d-4bdd-8bc1-3c657074670b)

The demo above shows the improved todo list with proper focus indicators and semantic structure. Users can now navigate todo items with arrow keys, and screen readers announce meaningful information about each item's status.

All changes preserve existing functionality while significantly improving accessibility for keyboard users and screen reader users.

Fixes #260833.

title: VS Code OAuth2 Flow Violates RFC 8707: Missing Resource Parameter in Token Exchange Request

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  Version: 1.104.0-insider (Universal)
- OS Version:  15.6 (24G84) MAC

**Problem**
VS Code's external authorization code request includes a resource indicator which allows AuthZ server to construct the token narrowly targeted for the protected resource (MCP server). However, VSCode doesn't include the same resource indicator into subsequent token request (exchange code for tokens) as mandated by rfc8707 (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8707#token-endpoint-example-ac). When resource indicator is present on the authorize request but is missing from the token request, some implementations of IDPs will fail to create an audience claim on the resulting token resulting in token validation failures on the protected resource (MCP server).

**Root Cause**
Missing check for the resource indicator leading to a missing resource indicator parameter in the exchange code for token request.

**Impact**
Token validation failures on the protected resource due to missing audience.

**Code Reference**
This code perhaps may be the cause
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/0e00a15ef0c59d39aff227c63fb3c55b1b25f9ac/src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostAuthentication.ts#L599

title: Don't see error state of coding agent session, and unsure why it failed
body: Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup) Commit: 97bc9a439c022a88fba7be68f67e068361f6c467 Date: 2025-08-12T17:22:21.373Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26100 I sent a follow-up to a completed coding agent session from VS Code by opening a chat editor with the session and sending a message (more details on steps I took here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/261359). The follow-up failed (I'm not sure if this was an issue on the VS Code or GH coding agent side?). Regardless, I see the error in gh.com: https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/3#issuecomment-3181323964 But I don't see it reflected anywhere in the session view or chat editor output: It's also worth noting that I don't actually see the follow-up message I sent in the above ^ (https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/3#issuecomment-3181323964) in my VS Code output anymore. When I opened the chat editor, it flickered and appeared briefly, and then it disappeared by the time I took this screenshot.

title: Looks like coding agent follow-ups get sent to both open chat sessions
body: Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup) Commit: 97bc9a439c022a88fba7be68f67e068361f6c467 Date: 2025-08-12T17:22:21.373Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26100 - Delegate a task to the coding agent via cloud button - Chat editor opens, streaming output from my new coding agent session - While that works, I want to explore and iterate on an existing completed coding agent session - I split my editor and open one of my complete coding agent sessions to the right, and I send a follow up message to it - ❓ The follow up gets sent to both sessions? So both the new in-progress session on the left and the completed session on the right This doesn't seem quite possible, so I decide to close both sessions. When I reopen the left session (which supposedly got interrupted), I see it is actually still working on its original task: So I think the issue is that the chat editor output got interrupted / overridden, but the actual session was (correctly) untouched. I was able to verify this should be the case by looking at the actual PRs in GitHub too: - This was the new session that was on the left. It looks like it (correctly) didn't get interrupted: https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/10 - This was the session where I sent a follow-up. I can see the follow-up: https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/3#issuecomment-3181323964 - Opened https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/261360 regarding failure of the follow-up

title: Fix terminal auto-approve to exclude command line arguments from subcommand suggestions
body:
The terminal auto-approve feature was incorrectly suggesting command line arguments as subcommands when they started with `-`. For example, when running `npm --foo --bar`, the dropdown would show "Always Allow Command: npm --foo" where `--foo` is clearly an argument/flag, not a legitimate npm subcommand.

![Image showing the incorrect suggestion](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4a3ae946-8b4d-4dc6-a139-0a43db39324f)

This fix adds validation to exclude arguments starting with `-` when generating subcommand suggestions for commands like npm, git, yarn, docker, etc.

## Changes

**Before:**
```typescript
} else if (commandsWithSubcommands.has(baseCommand) && parts.length >= 2) {
    return `${parts[0]} ${parts[1]}`;
}
```

**After:**
```typescript
} else if (commandsWithSubcommands.has(baseCommand) && parts.length >= 2 && !parts[1].startsWith('-')) {
    return `${parts[0]} ${parts[1]}`;
}
```

Applied the same validation for 3-part subcommands (like `npm run`).

## Behavior Changes

- `npm --foo --bar` → now suggests "Always Allow Command: npm" (was "npm --foo")
- `git --version` → now suggests "Always Allow Command: git" (was "git --version") 
- `npm run --verbose` → now suggests "Always Allow Command: npm run" (was "npm run --verbose")

Valid subcommands continue to work as expected:
- `npm install` → suggests "Always Allow Command: npm install" (unchanged)
- `npm run build` → suggests "Always Allow Command: npm run build" (unchanged)
- `git status` → suggests "Always Allow Command: git status" (unchanged)

Fixes #261346.

title: Want more task isolation when delegating to coding agent
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

My flow often looks like:
- Chatting with copilot (in Ask or local Agent mode) to do some planning or learning on my codebase
- As I learn new insight from copilot, I find new sub-tasks I want to delegate to the coding agent
- I use the cloud button to delegate the task
- I continue planning / learning, and then find another sub-task to delegate to the coding agent via the cloud button
- ❔ The second task I delegated ends up encompassing both the first and second tasks. I believe this is because Copilot is using my entire chat conversation at history, so since it sees sub-tasks 1 and 2, it wants to tackle both of them
     - Here are two example PRs: https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/3, https://github.com/bamurtaugh/NES-template/pull/4
     - I first just wanted to add a new Go example to my project, and then completely separately, I wanted to add a new notebook to my project. But PR 2 includes both the Go example and notebook

To an extent, this may require the coding agent itself to be more aware of previous and existing tasks, but I wonder if there's more we could do on the VS Code side too? i.e. any further prompting if we can detect if a user has moved on in their conversation, even if they're in the same chat session?

title: QuickPick — Add `noFiltering` option to `QuickPick`

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: quick-pick
labels.description: Quick-pick widget issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: ## Request Add support for a `noFiltering: boolean` (or similarly named) property on `QuickPick` returned by `vscode.window.createQuickPick()` in the stable extension API. Consequently, `QuickPickOptions` should have the same property — for `showQuickPick()`. ## Why This would let extension authors create simple dropdown UIs without a search box. This is useful for short lists or keyboard-only navigation when search/filtering is not required. ## Problem The filter input is always shown. Currently, there seems to be [no documented way](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#QuickInput) to disable or hide it. ## Specific Example Use Case * I want to present users with a small list of options (e.g., 3–5 items) where filtering is unnecessary. * I want to replicate a native dropdown or menu-like behavior, navigable by arrow keys. * The current `QuickPick` UI always includes a search box, which is redundant in this context. While hacks (like clearing the input value on change and retaining the placeholder) are possible, they are unreliable and have limitations. ## Related Issues [#90402](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/90402) — "Add quick pick option without input filtering"

title: Informe de Errores Evitables - Sesión de Corrección Scripts P2505-009
body:
# GitHub Copilot Issue Report - Codebase Verification Failures

## Issue Summary

**Title**: GitHub Copilot generates SQL code with invalid column/table references without verifying existing codebase

**Type**: Bug Report

**Priority**: High

**Component**: GitHub Copilot Extension for VS Code

---

## Brief Description of the Bug

GitHub Copilot consistently generates SQL code with invalid column names, table references, and schema inconsistencies without performing basic verification against the existing codebase. This results in multiple execution failures that could be prevented by consulting available source files.

The AI assistant generates code referencing non-existent database columns, uses incorrect table schemas, and creates inconsistent object definitions, despite having access to the actual database schema through the workspace files.

---

## Environment Information

### VS Code Version
- **VS Code Version**: 1.96.0 (latest as of December 2025)
- **GitHub Copilot Extension Version**: Latest available
- **Architecture**: x64

### OS Version
- **Operating System**: Windows 11 Pro
- **Version**: Latest updates applied
- **Shell**: PowerShell 7.x

### Extensions Status
- **Issue occurs with extensions disabled**: Unknown - requires testing
- **Current extension environment**: Multiple extensions active including SQL tools, Git integration

---

## Steps to Reproduce

### Context Setup
1. Open VS Code workspace containing SQL Server stored procedure files
2. Work with existing codebase containing:
   - Database table definitions
   - Stored procedure templates
   - Temporary table schemas
   - Previously working SQL scripts

### Reproduction Steps
1. Request GitHub Copilot to generate or correct SQL code
2. AI generates code referencing database objects
3. Execute generated SQL code
4. **Expected**: Code should reference valid, existing database objects
5. **Actual**: Code fails with "Invalid column name" or similar errors

### Specific Examples Encountered

#### Example 1: Invalid Column Reference
```sql
-- Generated by Copilot
LEFT JOIN dbo.vwLocal_SSI_Cmn_UDP scudp WITH (NOLOCK) 
ON scudp.[Value] = wed.WEFault_Value  -- INVALID COLUMN
```
**Error**: `Invalid column name 'WEFault_Value'`  
**Available in codebase**: `wed.WEFault_Id` (easily findable via search)

#### Example 2: Schema Inconsistency
```sql
-- Table creation by Copilot
SELECT 'WasteEventsAgg' AS Info, 'WASTE' AS Source,
    we.EventId,  -- MISSING: PUId, Machine, Roll, etc.
INTO ##WasteEventsAgg

-- Later INSERT by same Copilot session
INSERT INTO ##WasteEventsAgg (Info,Source,EventId,PUId,Machine,Roll,...)  -- FAILS
```
**Error**: `Invalid column name 'PUId'`

#### Example 3: Non-existent Field Usage
```sql
-- Generated by Copilot
ed.Event_Weight_EngUnit_Id AS WeightEngUnitId  -- DOES NOT EXIST
```
**Error**: `Invalid column name 'Event_Weight_EngUnit_Id'`

---

## Detailed Analysis

### Frequency of Issue
- **Occurrence**: 6 critical failures in single session
- **Pattern**: Consistent across different SQL operations
- **Preventability**: 100% of errors were avoidable through codebase verification

### Impact Assessment
- **Development Time**: Multiple hours lost to debugging preventable errors
- **User Frustration**: High - resulted in cancellation of Copilot Pro subscription
- **Code Quality**: Degraded due to multiple correction cycles
- **Trust in AI**: Significantly reduced

### Root Cause Analysis
The underlying issue appears to be that GitHub Copilot:
1. **Does not verify existing codebase** before generating object references
2. **Does not maintain consistency** between related code segments within the same session
3. **Does not perform basic syntax validation** on generated SQL
4. **Generates code iteratively** without holistic verification

---

## Evidence Documentation

### Error Log Sample
```
Error #1: SQL Server Database Error: Invalid column name 'WEFault_Value'
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_YieldReport.sql:978
Available: WEFault_Id (found via grep search in codebase)

Error #2: PL_Id Invalido  
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_YieldReport.sql
Schema: #Machines table does not contain PL_Id column
Available: PUId, PUDesc, EquipmentType, DeptId, DeptDesc

Error #3: SQL Server Database Error: Invalid column name 'Event_Weight_EngUnit_Id'
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_YieldReport.sql:964
Table: Event_Details does not contain this column
Available columns: Event_Id, Alternate_Event_Num, Initial_Dimension_Y, Initial_Dimension_Z

Error #4: SQL Server Database Error: Invalid column name 'PUId'
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_WasteReport.sql:720
Cause: Table ##WasteEventsAgg created with incomplete schema
Schema mismatch: CREATE vs INSERT operations inconsistent

Error #5: There is already an object named '#WasteReportDistinct'
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_WasteReport.sql (multiple instances)
Cause: Corrupted OBJECT_ID syntax: 'tempdb..#	INTO #WasteReportDistinct'
Correct: 'tempdb..#WasteReportDistinct'

Error #6: Field ShortCircuitDestination referenced but not populated
Location: Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_YieldReport.sql:990
Cause: UPDATE uses field not defined in preceding INSERT
```

### User Feedback Quotes
> "por favor hazme caso cuando te pido que revises todo"

> "Seguimos perdiendo muchos tiempos en errores tontos que pueden solucionarse si consultas la estructura de las tabla"

> "estoy cansado de ejecutar todo el tiempo scripts que no funcionan porque faltan campos"

> "Ya he dado de baja el Servicio Pro+ porque estaba cansado de estas inexactitudes tan obvias"

> "no entiendo porque tienen tantos problemas las IA de Copilot para resolver correctamente problemas básicos"

---

## Expected vs Actual Behavior

### Expected Behavior
1. **Codebase Verification**: AI should search existing files for valid column/table names before generating references
2. **Schema Consistency**: CREATE and INSERT operations should be consistent within the same session
3. **Incremental Validation**: Each generated code segment should be validated against previous segments
4. **Error Prevention**: Basic SQL syntax and object existence should be verified

### Actual Behavior
1. **No Verification**: AI generates invalid references without checking existing codebase
2. **Schema Conflicts**: CREATE and INSERT operations are inconsistent
3. **No Validation**: Code segments contradict each other within the same session
4. **Error Prone**: Multiple preventable SQL syntax and reference errors

---

## Proposed Solutions

### Short Term
1. **Implement codebase search** before generating database object references
2. **Add consistency checks** between related code segments in the same session
3. **Include basic SQL syntax validation** in the generation pipeline

### Long Term
1. **Context-aware code generation** that maintains schema consistency
2. **Proactive verification mode** that can be enabled for database-heavy projects
3. **Learning from corrections** to avoid repeating the same mistakes

---

## Reproducible Test Case

### Setup
Create a workspace with SQL files containing:
```sql
-- File: table_schema.sql
CREATE TABLE Event_Details (
    Event_Id INT,
    Alternate_Event_Num VARCHAR(50),
    Initial_Dimension_Y FLOAT,
    Initial_Dimension_Z FLOAT
    -- Note: Event_Weight_EngUnit_Id does NOT exist
);

CREATE TABLE Waste_Event_Details (
    WED_Id INT,
    WEFault_Id INT,  -- Note: WEFault_Value does NOT exist
    Event_Id INT,
    PU_Id INT
);
```

### Test Steps
1. Ask Copilot to generate SQL joining Event_Details
2. Observe if it references non-existent columns like `Event_Weight_EngUnit_Id`
3. Ask Copilot to generate SQL joining Waste_Event_Details
4. Observe if it references non-existent columns like `WEFault_Value`

### Expected Result
Copilot should only reference columns that exist in the schema files.

### Actual Result
Copilot generates references to non-existent columns, causing SQL execution failures.

---

## Additional Context

### Project Type
- **Domain**: Manufacturing Execution System (MES) database analysis
- **Files**: SQL Server stored procedures and analysis scripts
- **Complexity**: Multi-table joins, temporary tables, complex business logic

### Workspace Structure
```
MESEnhancements/
├── Scripts/
│   ├── Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_WasteReport.sql
│   ├── Script_spLocal_FIT_PBI_YieldReport.sql
│   └── Script_DBG_WasteYield_Compare.sql
└── soadb/
    └── Programmability/
        └── Procedures/
            └── [stored procedure definitions]
```

### Session Context
- **Duration**: Multi-hour debugging session
- **Iterations**: 6+ correction cycles
- **Files Modified**: 3 primary SQL scripts
- **Total Errors**: 6 critical SQL execution failures

---

## Request for Investigation

This issue significantly impacts developer productivity and trust in AI-assisted coding. The pattern of errors suggests a systematic gap in how GitHub Copilot handles database schema verification.

**Investigation Request:**
1. Review how Copilot verifies database object existence before code generation
2. Examine consistency checking between related code segments
3. Consider implementing workspace-aware schema validation
4. Evaluate feedback loops for learning from correction patterns

**Priority Justification:**
- High user impact (subscription cancellations)
- Preventable errors (100% avoidable through basic verification)
- Pattern of consistent failures across different SQL operations
- Direct effect on AI trustworthiness and adoption

---

## Contact Information

**Report Date**: December 12, 2025  
**Session ID**: P2505-009 Script Correction Session  
**User Impact**: High (Service cancellation due to reliability concerns)

title: Add auto-approval messages for global chat.tools.autoApprove setting
body:
When the global `"chat.tools.autoApprove": true` setting is enabled, terminal commands are automatically approved and executed without user confirmation. However, users were not informed why the command was auto-approved, leaving them without context about the automatic execution.

This change adds clear messaging to inform users when commands are auto-approved due to the global setting:

**Before:** Commands auto-approved by the global setting showed no explanation
**After:** Commands show "_Auto approved by global tools setting_" message

## Changes Made

### 1. Enhanced Auto-Approval Detection (`languageModelToolsService.ts`)
- Modified `shouldAutoConfirm()` to return detailed information about the auto-approval source
- Added logic to set `autoApproveInfo` in terminal tool data when the global setting triggers auto-approval
- Preserves existing terminal-specific auto-approval messages (they take precedence over global messages)

### 2. Updated Message Display (`chatTerminalToolProgressPart.ts`)
- Modified content rendering to include `autoApproveInfo` when present
- Ensures the auto-approval message appears below the command in the chat interface

## Behavior
- When `"chat.tools.autoApprove": true` is set, users now see a clear message explaining the auto-approval
- Terminal-specific auto-approval rules continue to work as before and show their own messages
- No changes to auto-approval functionality - only adds user-facing messaging for transparency

The fix ensures users understand when and why their commands are being automatically executed, improving the overall user experience and transparency of the auto-approval system.

Fixes #261319.

title: Fix InstantiationService disposal error in terminal tab rendering
body:
This PR fixes a race condition where the `InstantiationService` is disposed while terminal tab rendering is still in progress, causing the error:

```
Error: InstantiationService has been disposed
at b.m in src/vs/platform/instantiation/common/instantiationService.ts:69:10
at b.invokeFunction in src/vs/platform/instantiation/common/instantiationService.ts:90:8
at q.renderElement in src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/browser/terminalTabsList.ts:337:45
```

The issue occurs during workbench shutdown or cleanup when:
1. The `InstantiationService` gets disposed
2. Terminal tabs are still actively rendering elements
3. The renderer tries to call `invokeFunction(getIconId, instance)` on the disposed service

## Changes Made

**Added defensive error handling in three locations:**

1. **`terminalTabsList.ts` - `renderElement()` method**: Wraps the `invokeFunction(getIconId, instance)` call with a try-catch that falls back to the default terminal icon (`Codicon.terminal.id`) when the service is disposed.

2. **`terminalTabsList.ts` - `renderTemplate()` method**: Wraps the `createInstance(MenuEntryActionViewItem)` call with a try-catch that returns `undefined` for graceful degradation when the service is disposed.

3. **`terminalView.ts` - `updateLabel()` method**: Wraps the `invokeFunction(getSingleTabLabel)` call with a try-catch that falls back to a simple terminal label format when the service is disposed.

All error handlers specifically check for the "InstantiationService has been disposed" error message and provide appropriate fallbacks while re-throwing any other unexpected errors.

## Testing

Added a comprehensive unit test that validates the disposal handling behavior and confirms that the expected error message is correctly caught by our defensive code.

The fix is minimal and surgical, only adding error handling where the `InstantiationService` is used during rendering operations that can occur after disposal, ensuring the terminal UI degrades gracefully instead of throwing errors.

Fixes #216575.

title: Fix WSL access when useWslProfiles is disabled
body:
VSCode was accessing `c:\windows\system32\wsl.exe` on startup even when `terminal.integrated.useWslProfiles: false` was explicitly set in user settings. This caused security exceptions in restricted environments where wsl.exe access is blocked.

## Root Cause

Two code paths were calling wsl.exe without respecting the `useWslProfiles` configuration:

1. **WSLContextKeyInitializer** unconditionally called `hasWSLFeatureInstalled()` during startup to set context keys, regardless of user preferences
2. **getWslProfiles()** function lacked defense-in-depth protection against potential configuration bypasses

## Solution

### Fixed WSL Context Key Initialization
Modified `WSLContextKeyInitializer` to check the `terminal.integrated.useWslProfiles` setting before calling `hasWSLFeatureInstalled()`. This prevents the primary startup wsl.exe access issue.

### Added Defense-in-Depth Protection
Enhanced `getWslProfiles()` with an explicit safety check that returns early when `useWslProfiles` is `false`, providing an additional layer of protection beyond existing guard conditions.

### Added Test Coverage
Created a test case to verify wsl.exe is not called when `useWslProfiles: false`, ensuring this security issue doesn't regress.

## User Impact

Users in restricted environments can now safely set:
```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.useWslProfiles": false
}
```

This completely prevents VSCode from accessing wsl.exe during startup or profile detection, resolving security policy violations while maintaining all other functionality.

Fixes #257269.

title: `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove`: Quoted curly braces {} cause incorrect sub-command split and block auto-approval

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
## Description
When using `"chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove": { "echo": true }`, simple `echo` commands auto-approve correctly.  
However, if the echoed string contains curly braces `{}` — even inside **single quotes** — VS Code’s auto-approve engine incorrectly splits the command into multiple sub-commands and blocks auto-approval.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. In `settings.json`:
   ```jsonc
   "chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove": {
     "echo": true
   }
   ```
2. Open Copilot Chat or agent mode terminal.  
3. Run:
   ```bash
   echo 'query { test }'
   ```
4. Observe: permission is requested despite `echo` being whitelisted.

## Expected Behavior
- The entire `echo 'query { test }'` command should match the `echo` allow rule and auto-approve, because `{}` is inside single quotes and is just literal text.

## Actual Behavior
- VS Code parses the quoted braces as a command separator, incorrectly treating the line as two sub-commands.  
- Since the second sub-command has no matching allow rule, the whole line fails auto-approval.

## Logs (from Terminal output channel)
```
2025-08-12 20:15:10.451 [info] autoApprove: Command line NOT auto-approved []
2025-08-12 20:15:10.451 [info] - Command 'echo 'query' is approved by allow list rule: echo []
2025-08-12 20:15:10.451 [info] - Command 'test }'' has no matching auto approve entries []
2025-08-12 20:15:10.451 [info] - Command line 'echo 'query { test }'' has no matching auto approve entries []
```

title: Add empty state message and create button for local chat sessions
body:
This PR adds an empty state message for local chat sessions along with a primary button that allows users to create a new chat session directly from the empty state.

## Changes Made

### Core Functionality
- Modified `showEmptyMessage()` method to display empty state for **both** local and non-local providers
- Added localized empty state message specifically for local chat sessions: "Start a new chat session to begin"
- Added a primary "New Chat" button that executes the `workbench.action.openChat` command

### Implementation Details
- **Updated imports**: Added `Button` UI component, `ICommandService`, and `defaultButtonStyles`
- **Updated constructor**: Added `ICommandService` injection to `SessionsViewPane` 
- **Enhanced message display**:
  - Local providers: Shows "Start a new chat session to begin" with a "New Chat" button
  - Non-local providers: Keeps existing "No sessions found for {providerName}" message
- **Button functionality**: Uses existing `workbench.action.openChat` command (already available in menu bar)
- **Styling**: Follows VS Code design patterns using `defaultButtonStyles`
- **Lifecycle management**: Proper disposal and cleanup of button components

### Benefits
- **Better UX**: Provides clear guidance when no chat sessions exist
- **Direct Action**: Users can immediately create a new chat without navigating to menus
- **Consistent**: Maintains existing behavior for extension-provided session providers
- **Accessible**: Button includes proper aria labels and follows VS Code accessibility patterns

### Technical Notes

title: Add description and status properties to ChatSessionItem interface
body:
This PR enhances the `ChatSessionItem` interface by adding two new optional properties to provide richer context about chat sessions:

## New Properties

### `description?: string`
An optional description field that provides additional context about the chat session. This description is displayed below the session name in the chat sessions view, giving users more information about what each session contains.

### `status?: ChatSessionStatus`
An optional status enum indicating the current state of the session. The new `ChatSessionStatus` enum includes:
- `Failed = 0` - The chat session failed to complete
- `Completed = 1` - The chat session completed successfully  
- `InProgress = 2` - The chat session is currently in progress

## Implementation Details

**API Changes:**
- Added `ChatSessionStatus` enum to `vscode.proposed.chatSessionsProvider.d.ts`
- Extended `ChatSessionItem` interface with the new optional properties
- Both properties maintain full backward compatibility

**Internal Updates:**
- Updated `IChatSessionItem` in `chatSessionsService.ts` to mirror the API changes
- Added corresponding enum definition for internal use
- Updated `ILocalChatSessionItem` to include the status property

**Extension Host Integration:**
- Modified `extHostChatSessions.ts` to properly pass through the new properties from extension providers to the main thread

**UI Support:**
- The existing `SessionsRenderer` already supports displaying descriptions below session names
- Status information can be used by extensions to provide visual indicators of session state

## Usage Example

Extensions can now provide richer session information:

```typescript
const sessions: vscode.ChatSessionItem[] = [
    {
        id: 'session-1',
        label: 'Code Review Session',
        description: 'Discussion about pull request #123 changes',
        status: vscode.ChatSessionStatus.Completed,
        iconPath: new vscode.ThemeIcon('git-pull-request')
    },
    {
        id: 'session-2',
        label: 'Debug Session', 
        description: 'Troubleshooting memory leak in production',
        status: vscode.ChatSessionStatus.InProgress,
        iconPath: new vscode.ThemeIcon('bug')
    }
];
```

This enhancement follows VS Code's existing API patterns and maintains full backward compatibility since both properties are optional.
